question: You MUST NOT enter a road, lane or other route reserved for trams. Take extra care where trams run along the road. You should avoid driving directly on top of the rails and should take care where trams leave the main carriageway to enter the reserved route, to ensure you do not follow them. What the markup specified by tram lines?
answer: On the tram lines are white lines and yellow dots

question: Take extra care where the track crosses from one side of the road to the other and where the road narrows and the tracks come close to the kerb. Tram drivers usually have their own traffic signals and may be permitted to move when you are not. ...
answer: ...Always give way to trams. Do not try to race or overtake them or pass them on the inside, unless they are at tram stops or stopped by tram signals and there is a designated tram lane for you to pass.

question: You MUST NOT park your vehicle where it would get in the way of trams or where it would force other drivers to do so. Do not stop on any part of a tram track, ...
answer: ...except in a designated bay where this has been provided alongside and clear of the track. When doing so, ensure that all parts of your vehicle are outside the delineated tram path. Remember that a tram cannot steer round an obstruction.

question: Tram stops. Where the tram stops at a platform, either in the middle or at the side of the road, you MUST follow the route shown by the road signs and markings. At stops without platforms you...
answer: ...MUST NOT drive between a tram and the left-hand kerb when a tram has stopped to pick up passengers. If there is no alternative route signed, do not overtake the tram - wait until it moves off.

question: Look out for pedestrians, and ...
answer: ...especially children, running to catch a tram approaching a stop.

question: Always give priority to trams, especially when they signal to pull away from stops, unless it would be unsafe to do so. Remember that they may be carrying large numbers of standing passengers who could be injured if the tram had to make an emergency stop. What to look out for at the tram stop?
answer: Look out for people getting off a bus or tram and crossing the road.

question: All road users, but particularly cyclists and motorcyclists, should take extra care when driving or riding close to or crossing the tracks, especially if the rails are wet. You should take particular care when crossing the rails at shallow angles, on bends and at junctions. How to safely cross the tram tracks?
answer: It is safest to cross the tracks directly at right angles.

question: Overhead electric lines. What tramway overhead wires are normally above any carriageway?
answer: ...5.8 metres, but can be lower.

question: A level crossing is where a road crosses a railway or tramway line. Approach and cross it with care. Never drive...
answer: ...onto a crossing until the road is clear on the other side and do not get too close to the car in front. Never stop or park on, or near, a crossing.

question: It is dangerous to touch overhead electric lines. You MUST obey the safe height warning road signs and you should not continue forward onto the railway if your vehicle touches any height barrier or bells. What is the clearance suppose to electric lines?
answer: The clearance available is usually 5 metres (16 feet 6 inches) but may be lower.

question: Controlled Crossings. Most crossings have traffic light signals with a steady amber light, twin flashing red stop lights  and an audible alarm for pedestrians. They may have full, half or no barriers. What you must:
answer:
a)You MUST always obey the flashing red stop lights.
b)You MUST stop behind the white line across the road.
c)Keep going if you have already crossed the white line when the amber light comes on.
d)Do not reverse onto or over a controlled crossing.
e)You MUST wait if a train goes by and the red lights continue to flash. This means another train will be passing soon.
f)Only cross when the lights go off and barriers open.

question: Railway telephones. If you are driving a large or slow- moving vehicle, a long, low vehicle with a risk of grounding, or herding animals, a train could arrive before you are clear of the crossing. You MUST...
answer: ...obey any sign instructing you to use the railway telephone to obtain permission to cross. You MUST also telephone when clear of the crossing if requested to do so.

question: Crossings without traffic lights. Vehicles should stop and wait at the barrier or gate when it begins to close and...
answer: ...not cross until the barrier or gate opens.

question: User-operated gates or barriers. Some crossings have ‘Stop’ signs and small red and green lights. You MUST NOT cross when the red light is showing, only cross if the green light is on. If crossing with a vehicle, you should:
answer:
a)open the gates or barriers on both sides of the crossing.
b)check that the green light is still on and cross quickly.
c)close the gates or barriers when you are clear of the crossing.

question: If there are no lights,...
answer: ...Stop, look both ways and listen before you cross.

question: Open crossings. These have no gates, barriers, attendant or traffic lights but will have a ‘Give Way’ sign. You should...
answer: ...look both ways, listen and make sure there is no train coming before you cross.

question: Incidents and breakdowns. If your vehicle breaks down, or if you have an incident on a crossing you should:
answer:
a)get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing immediately.
b)use a railway telephone if available to tell the signal operator. Follow the instructions you are given.
c)move the vehicle clear of the crossing if there is time before a train arrives. If the alarm sounds, or the amber light comes on, leave the vehicle and get clear of the crossing immediately.

question: When the ‘Road Works Ahead’ sign is displayed, you will need to be more watchful and look for additional signs providing more specific instructions. Observe all signs - they are there for your safety and the safety of road workers.
answer:
a)You MUST NOT exceed any temporary maximum speed limit.
b)Use your mirrors and get into the correct lane for your vehicle in good time and as signs direct.
c)Do not switch lanes to overtake queuing traffic.
d)Take extra care near cyclists and motorcyclists as they are vulnerable to skidding on grit, mud or other debris at road works.
e)Where lanes are restricted due to road works, merge in turn.
f)Do not drive through an area marked off by traffic cones.
g)Watch out for traffic entering or leaving the works area, but do not be distracted by what is going on there. Concentrate on the road ahead, not the road works.
h)Bear in mind that the road ahead may be obstructed by the works or by slow moving or stationary traffic.
i)Keep a safe distance - there could be queues in front. To obtain further information about road works.

question: If your vehicle breaks down, think first of all other road users and:
answer:
a)get your vehicle off the road if possible
b)warn other traffic by using your hazard warning lights if your vehicle is causing an obstruction.
c)help other road users see you by wearing light-coloured or fluorescent clothing in daylight and reflective clothing at night or in poor visibility.
d)put a warning triangle on the road at least 45 metres (147 feet) behind your broken-down vehicle on the same side of the road, or use other permitted warning devices if you have them. Always take great care when placing or retrieving them, but never use them on motorways.
e)if possible, keep your sidelights on if it is dark or visibility is poor.
f)do not stand (or let anybody else stand) between your vehicle and oncoming traffic.
g)at night or in poor visibility do not stand where you will prevent other road users seeing your lights.

question: If anything falls from your vehicle (or any other vehicle) on to the road,...
answer: ...stop and retrieve it only if it is safe to do so.

question: Motorways. On a motorway do not try to remove the obstruction yourself. Stop at the next emergency telephone and...
answer: ...call the Highways Agency or the police.

question: Warning signs or flashing lights. If you see or hear emergency or incident support vehicles in the distance, be aware there may be an incident ahead (see Rule 219). Police Officers and Highways Agency Traffic Officers may be required to work in the carriageway, for example dealing with debris, collisions or conducting rolling road blocks. Police officers will use rear-facing flashing red and blue lights and HA Traffic Officers will use rear-facing flashing red and amber lights in these situations. Watch out for such signals, slow down and be prepared to stop. You MUST...
answer: ...follow any directions given by Police officers or Traffic officers as to whether you can safely pass the incident or blockage.

question: When passing the scene of an incident or crash do not be distracted or slow down unnecessarily because...
answer: This may cause a collision or traffic congestion.

question: If you are involved in a crash or stop to give assistance:
answer:
a)use your hazard warning lights to warn other traffic.
b)ask drivers to switch off their engines and stop smoking.
c)arrange for the emergency services to be called immediately with full details of the incident location and any casualties (on a motorway, use the emergency telephone which allows easy location by the emergency services. If you use a mobile phone, first make sure you have identified your location from the marker posts on the side of the hard shoulder).
d)move uninjured people away from the vehicles to safety; on a motorway this should, if possible, be well away from the traffic, the hard shoulder and the central reservation.
e)do not move injured people from their vehicles unless they are in immediate danger from fire or explosion.
f)do not remove a motorcyclist’s helmet unless it is essential to do so.
g)stay at the scene until emergency services arrive. If you are involved in any other medical emergency on the motorway you should contact the emergency services in the same way.

question: What markings should be on the vehicles carrying dangerous goods in packages, road tankers and vehicles carrying tank containers of dangerous goods?
answer: Will be marked with plain orange reflective plates and hazard warning plates

question: If an incident involves a vehicle containing dangerous goods, follow the advice:
answer:
a)switch off engines and DO NOT SMOKE.
b)keep well away from the vehicle and do not be tempted to try to rescue casualties as you yourself could become one.
c)call the emergency services and give as much information as possible about the labels and markings on the vehicle. DO NOT use a mobile phone close to a vehicle carrying flammable loads.

question: If you are involved in a collision which causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property, you MUST
answer:
a)stop.
b)give your own and the vehicle owner’s name and address, and the registration number of the vehicle, to anyone having reasonable grounds for requiring them.
c)if you do not give your name and address at the time of the collision, report it to the police as soon as reasonably practicable, and in any case within 24 hours.

question: If another person is injured and you do not produce your insurance certificate at the time of the crash to a police officer or to anyone having reasonable grounds to request it, you MUST
answer:
a)report it to the police as soon as possible and in any case within 24 hours.
b)produce your insurance certificate for the police within seven days.

question: Prohibited vehicles. Motorways MUST NOT be used by...
answer: ...pedestrians, holders of provisional motorcycle or car licences, riders of motorcycles under 50 cc, cyclists, horse riders, certain slow-moving vehicles and those carrying oversized loads (except by special permission), agricultural vehicles, and powered wheelchairs/powered mobility scooters

question: Traffic on motorways usually travels faster than on other roads, so you have less time to react. It is especially important to use your mirrors earlier and...
answer: ...look much further ahead than you would on other roads.

question: Why use motorways signals?
answer: For example, there may be an incident, fog, a spillage or road workers on the carriageway which you may not immediately be able to see.

question: Signals situated on the central reservation apply to all lanes. What signals use on very busy stretches?
answer: On very busy stretches, signals may be overhead with a separate signal for each lane.

question: What warning amber flashing lights?
answer: These warn of a hazard ahead. The signal may show a temporary maximum speed limit, lanes that are closed or a message such as ‘Fog’

question: Red flashing lights. If red lights flash on a signal in the central reservation or at the side of the road, you MUST NOT...
answer: ...go beyond the signal in any lane.

question: Joining the motorway. When you join the motorway you will normally approach it from a road on the left (a slip road) or from an adjoining motorway. You should:
answer:
a)give priority to traffic already on the motorway.
b)check the traffic on the motorway and match your speed to fit safely into the traffic flow in the left-hand lane.
c)not cross solid white lines that separate lanes or use the hard shoulder.
d)stay on the slip road if it continues as an extra lane on the motorway.
e)remain in the left-hand lane long enough to adjust to the speed of traffic before considering overtaking.

question: When you can see well ahead and the road conditions are good, you should:
answer:
a)drive at a steady cruising speed which you and your vehicle can handle safely and is within the speed limit.
b)keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front and increase the gap on wet or icy roads, or in fog.

question: If you have missed your exit, or have taken the wrong route, carry on to the next exit, but you MUST NOT
answer: ...reverse.

question: You should always drive in the left-hand lane when the road ahead is clear. If you are overtaking a number of slower-moving vehicles, you should...
answer: ...return to the left-hand lane as soon as you are safely past.

question: The right-hand lane of a motorway with three or more lanes MUST NOT be used (except in prescribed circumstances) if you are driving:
answer:
a)any vehicle drawing a trailer.
b)a goods vehicle with a maximum laden weight exceeding 3.5 tonnes but not exceeding 7.5 tonnes, which is required to be fitted with a speed limiter.
c)a goods vehicle with a maximum laden weight exceeding 7.5 tonnes.
d)a passenger vehicle with a maximum laden weight exceeding 7.5 tonnes constructed or adapted to carry more than eight seated passengers in addition to the driver.
e)a passenger vehicle with a maximum laden weight not exceeding 7.5 tonnes which is constructed or adapted to carry more than eight seated passengers in addition to the driver, which is required to be fitted with a speed limiter.

question: Do not overtake unless you are sure it is safe and legal to do so. Overtake only on the right. You should:
answer:
a)check your mirrors.
b)take time to judge the speeds correctly.
c)make sure that the lane you will be joining is sufficiently clear ahead and behind.
d)take a quick sideways glance into the blind spot area to verify the position of a vehicle that may have disappeared from your view in the mirror.
e)remember that traffic may be coming up behind you very quickly. Check all your mirrors carefully. Look out for motorcyclists. When it is safe to do so, signal in plenty of time, then move out.
f)ensure you do not cut in on the vehicle you have overtaken.
g)be especially careful at night and in poor visibility when it is harder to judge speed and distance.

question: Hard shoulder. You MUST NOT use the hard shoulder for ...
answer: ...overtaking

question: You MUST NOT stop on the carriageway, hard shoulder, slip road, central reservation or verge except...
answer: ...in an emergency, or when told to do so by the police, HA traffic officers in uniform, an emergency sign or by flashing red light signals.

question: You MUST NOT pick up or set down anyone, or walk on a motorway, except ...
answer: ...in an emergency.

question: Unless signs indicate that a lane leads directly off the motorway, you will normally leave the motorway by a slip road on your left. You should:
answer:
a)watch for the signs letting you know you are getting near your exit.
b)move into the left-hand lane well before reaching your exit.
c)signal left in good time and reduce your speed on the slip road as necessary.

question: On leaving the motorway or using a link road between motorways, your speed may be higher than you realise - 50 mph may feel like 30 mph. What you need to check?
answer: Check your speedometer and adjust your speed accordingly.

question: You MUST NOT wait or park on...
answer: ...yellow lines during the times of operation shown on nearby time plates and 'Road markings'.

question: Use off-street parking areas, or bays marked out with white lines on the road as parking places, wherever possible. If you have to stop on the roadside:
answer:
a)do not park facing against the traffic flow.
b)stop as close as you can to the side.
c)do not stop too close to a vehicle displaying a Blue Badge: remember, the occupant may need more room to get in or out.
d)you MUST switch off the engine, headlights and fog lights.
e)you MUST apply the handbrake before leaving the vehicle.
f)you MUST ensure you do not hit anyone when you open your door. Check for cyclists or other traffic.
g)it is safer for your passengers (especially children) to get out of the vehicle on the side next to the kerb.
h)put all valuables out of sight and make sure your vehicle is secure

question: You MUST NOT stop or park on:
answer:
a)the carriageway or the hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency.
b)a pedestrian crossing, including the area marked by the zig-zag lines.
c)a clearway.
d)taxi bays as indicated by upright signs and markings.
e)an Urban Clearway within its hours of operation, except to pick up or set down passengers.
f)a road marked with double white lines, even when a broken white line is on your side of the road, except to pick up or set down passengers, or to load or unload goods.
g)a tram or cycle lane during its period of operation.
h)a cycle track

question: You MUST NOT park in parking spaces reserved for specific users, such as...
answer: ...Blue Badge holders, residents or motorcycles, unless entitled to do so.

question: You MUST NOT leave your vehicle or trailer in a dangerous position or...
answer: ...where it causes any unnecessary obstruction of the road.

question: DO NOT stop or park:
answer:
a)near a school entrance.
b)anywhere you would prevent access for Emergency Services.
c)at or near a bus or tram stop or taxi rank.
d)on the approach to a level crossing/tramway crossing.
e)opposite or within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction, except in an authorised parking space.
f)near the brow of a hill or hump bridge.
g)opposite a traffic island or (if this would cause an obstruction) another parked vehicle.
h)where you would force other traffic to enter a tram lane.
i)where the kerb has been lowered to help wheelchair users and powered mobility vehicles.

question: You MUST NOT park partially or wholly on the pavement in London, and should not do so elsewhere unless signs permit it. Parking on the pavement can obstruct and...
answer: ...seriously inconvenience pedestrians, people in wheelchairs or with visual impairments and people with prams or pushchairs.

question: What is the Controlled Parking Zones?
answer: The zone entry signs indicate the times when the waiting restrictions within the zone are in force. Parking may be allowed in some places at other times.

question: Goods vehicles. Vehicles with a maximum laden weight of over 7.5 tonnes (including any trailer) MUST NOT be parked on a verge, pavement or any land situated between carriageways, without police permission. The only exception is...
answer: ...when parking is essential for loading and unloading, in which case the vehicle MUST NOT be left unattended.

question: You MUST NOT park on a road at night facing...
answer: ...against the direction of the traffic flow unless in a recognised parking space.

question: All vehicles MUST display parking lights when parked on a road or a lay-by on a road with a speed limit...
answer: ...greater than 30 mph (48 km/h).

question: Cars, goods vehicles not exceeding 1525 kg unladen weight, invalid carriages, motorcycles and pedal cycles may be parked without lights on a road (or lay-by) with a speed limit of 30 mph (48 km/h) or less if they are:
answer:
a)at least 10 metres (32 feet) away from any junction, close to the kerb and facing in the direction of the traffic flow.
b)in a recognised parking place or lay-by.

question: Parking in fog. It is especially dangerous to park on the road in fog. What to take to secure parking?
answer: If it is unavoidable, leave your parking lights or sidelights on.

question: Parking on hills. If you park on a hill you should:
answer:
a)park close to the kerb and apply the handbrake firmly.
b)select a forward gear and turn your steering wheel away from the kerb when facing uphill.
c)select reverse gear and turn your steering wheel towards the kerb when facing downhill.
d)use ‘park’ if your car has an automatic gearbox.

question: You MUST use headlights when visibility is seriously reduced, generally when you cannot see for more than...
answer: ...100 metres (328 feet).

question: Wet weather. In wet weather, stopping distances will be at least double those required for stopping on dry roads. This is because your tyres have less grip on the road. In wet weather:
answer:
a)you should keep well back from the vehicle in front. This will increase your ability to see and plan ahead.
b)if the steering becomes unresponsive, it probably means that water is preventing the tyres from gripping the road. Ease off the accelerator and slow down gradually.
c)the rain and spray from vehicles may make it difficult to see and be seen.
d)be aware of the dangers of spilt diesel that will make the surface very slippery.
e)take extra care around pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and horse riders.

question: In winter check the local weather forecast for warnings of icy or snowy weather. DO NOT drive in these conditions unless your journey is essential. If it is, take great care and allow more time for your journey. Take an emergency kit. What is the emergency kit?
answer: It's de-icer and ice scraper, torch, warm clothing and boots, first aid kit, jump leads and a shovel, together with a warm drink and emergency food in case you get stuck or your vehicle breaks down.

question: Before you set off:
answer:
a)you MUST be able to see, so clear all snow and ice from all your windows.
b)you MUST ensure that lights are clean and number plates are clearly visible and legible.
c)make sure the mirrors are clear and the windows are demisted thoroughly.
d)remove all snow that might fall off into the path of other road users.
e)check your planned route is clear of delays and that no further snowfalls or severe weather are predicted.

question: When driving in icy or snowy weather:
answer:
a)drive with care, even if the roads have been treated.
b)keep well back from the road user in front as stopping distances can be ten times greater than on dry roads.
c)take care when overtaking vehicles spreading salt or other de-icer, particularly if you are riding a motorcycle or cycle.
d)watch out for snowploughs which may throw out snow on either side. Do not overtake them unless the lane you intend to use has been cleared.
e)be prepared for the road conditions to change over relatively short distances.
f)listen to travel bulletins and take note of variable message signs that may provide information about weather, road and traffic conditions ahead.

question: Drive extremely carefully when the roads are icy. Avoid sudden actions as these could cause loss of control. You should:
answer:
a)drive at a slow speed in as high a gear as possible; accelerate and brake very gently.
b)drive particularly slowly on bends where loss of control is more likely. Brake progressively on the straight before you reach a bend. Having slowed down, steer smoothly round the bend, avoiding sudden actions.
c)check your grip on the road surface when there is snow or ice by choosing a safe place to brake gently. If the steering feels unresponsive this may indicate ice and your vehicle losing its grip on the road. When travelling on ice, tyres make virtually no noise.

question: When driving in fog you should:
answer:
a)use your lights as required.
b)keep a safe distance behind the vehicle in front. Rear lights can give a false sense of security.
c)be able to pull up well within the distance you can see clearly. This is particularly important on motorways and dual carriageways, as vehicles are travelling faster.
d)use your windscreen wipers and demisters.
e)beware of other drivers not using headlights.
f)not accelerate to get away from a vehicle which is too close behind you.
g)check your mirrors before you slow down. Then use your brakes so that your brake lights warn drivers behind you that you are slowing down.

question: You MUST NOT use front or rear fog lights unless visibility is seriously reduced because...
answer: ...they dazzle other road users and can obscure your brake lights. You MUST switch them off when visibility improves.

question: Who are the most vulnerable road users?
answer: It's pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and horse riders. It is particularly important to be aware of children, older and disabled people, and learner and inexperienced drivers and riders.

question: Drive carefully and slowly when:
answer:
a)in crowded shopping streets, Home Zones and Quiet Lanes or residential areas.
b)driving past bus and tram stops; pedestrians may emerge suddenly into the road.
c)passing parked vehicles, especially ice cream vans; children are more interested in ice cream than traffic and may run into the road unexpectedly.
d)needing to cross a pavement or cycle track; for example, to reach or leave a driveway. Give way to pedestrians and cyclists on the pavement.
e)reversing into a side road; look all around the vehicle and give way to any pedestrians who may be crossing the road.
f)turning at road junctions; give way to pedestrians who are already crossing the road into which you are turning.
g)the pavement is closed due to street repairs and pedestrians are directed to use the road.
h)approaching pedestrians on narrow rural roads without a footway or footpath. Always slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary, giving them plenty of room as you drive past.

question: Particularly vulnerable pedestrians. These include:
answer:
a)children and older pedestrians who may not be able to judge your speed and could step into the road in front of you. At 40 mph (64 km/h) your vehicle will probably kill any pedestrians it hits. At 20 mph (32 km/h) there is only a 1 in 20 chance of the pedestrian being killed. So kill your speed.
b)older pedestrians who may need more time to cross the road. Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time. Do not hurry them by revving your engine or edging forward.
c)people with disabilities. People with hearing impairments may not be aware of your vehicle approaching. Those with walking difficulties require more time.
d)blind or partially sighted people, who may be carrying a white cane using a guide dog. They may not be able to see you approaching.
e)deafblind people who may be carrying a white cane with a red band or using a dog with a red and white harness. They may not see or hear instructions or signals.

question: How to move near schools?
answer: Drive slowly and be particularly aware of young cyclists and pedestrians.

question: What you MUST, when a school crossing patrol shows a ‘Stop for children’ sign?
answer: You MUST stop!

question: Motorcyclists and cyclists may suddenly need to avoid uneven road surfaces and obstacles such as drain covers or oily, wet or icy patches on the road. Give them...
answer: ...plenty of room and pay particular attention to any sudden change of direction they may have to make.

question: Animals. When passing animals, drive slowly. Give them plenty of room and be ready to stop. Do not scare animals by sounding your horn, revving your engine or accelerating rapidly once you have passed them. What you need if a road is blocked by a herd of animals?
answer: You MUST stop and switch off your engine until they have left the road.

question: As noted a new driver?
answer: Drivers who have recently passed their test may display a ‘new driver’ plate or sticker.

question: What it is Home Zones and Quiet Lanes?
answer: These are places where people could be using the whole of the road for a range of activities such as children playing or for a community event.

question: What it is Emergency and Incident Support vehicles?
answer: It is ambulances, fire engines, police, doctors or other emergency vehicles using flashing blue, red or green lights and sirens or flashing headlights, or Highways Agency Traffic Officer and Incident Support vehicles using flashing amber lights.

question: Are subject to a speed limit large vehicles?
answer: Yes!

question: What it is Electric vehicles?
answer: It is milk floats and trams.

question: How to make you vehicle around?
answer: If you need to turn your vehicle around, wait until you find a safe place. Try not to reverse or turn round in a busy road; find a quiet side road or drive round a block of side streets.

question: Look carefully before you start reversing. You should:
answer: a)use all your mirrors.b)check the ‘blind spot’ behind you (the part of the road you cannot see easily in the mirrors).c)check there are no pedestrians (particularly children), cyclists, other road users or obstructions in the road behind you.

question: Zebra crossings. As you approach a zebra crossing
answer:
a)look out for pedestrians waiting to cross and be ready to slow down or stop to let them cross.
b)you MUST give way when a pedestrian has moved onto a crossing.
c)allow more time for stopping on wet or icy roads.
d)do not wave or use your horn to invite pedestrians across; this could be dangerous if another vehicle is approaching.
e)be aware of pedestrians approaching from the side of the crossing.

question: What it is Pelican crossings?
answer: These are signal-controlled crossings where flashing amber follows the red ‘Stop’ light. You MUST stop when the red light shows. When the amber light is flashing, you MUST give way to any pedestrians on the crossing. If the amber light is flashing and there are no pedestrians on the crossing, you may proceed with caution.

question: Pelican crossings which go straight across the road are one crossing, even when there is a central island. You MUST...
answer: ...wait for pedestrians who are crossing from the other side of the island.

question: What it is toucan, puffin and equestrian crossings?
answer: These are similar to pelican crossings, but there is no flashing amber phase; the light sequence for traffic at these three crossings is the same as at traffic lights. If the signal-controlled crossing is not working, proceed with extreme caution.

question: On approaching a roundabout take notice and act on all the information available to you, including traffic signs, traffic lights and lane markings which direct you into the correct lane. You should:
answer:
a)use Mirrors – Signal – Manoeuvre at all stages.
b)decide as early as possible which exit you need to take.
c)give an appropriate signal (see Rule 186, below). Time your signals so as not to confuse other road users.
d)get into the correct lane.
e)adjust your speed and position to fit in with traffic conditions

question: When reaching the roundabout you should
answer:
a)give priority to traffic approaching from your right, unless directed otherwise by signs, road markings or traffic lights.

question: When turning right at crossroads where an oncoming vehicle is also turning right, there is a choice of two methods
